expectations:
- Prepare students for web developer roles
      - MUST be in US English

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Outstanding scope and organization covering everything from foundations to advanced topics. Exceptional structure balancing depth and breadth: detailed frontend (including design tokens, ARIA, advanced browser APIs), thorough backend (event sourcing, CQRS, DDD), extensive DevOps/cloud coverage, and unique valuable chapters like AI integration, collaboration/sync, supply chain security. Titles are concise and descriptions avoid fluff. Covers latest trends (WebAssembly, edge computing, LLMs) without vendor name violations. Progressive learning path from fundamentals to mastery. Well-organized 137 chapters provide comprehensive coverage for top 1% preparation without being overwhelming.

Excellent comprehensive coverage with 58 well-structured chapters. Strong progression from CS foundations through advanced system design. Includes valuable unique topics: gRPC, cryptography, SRE practices, chaos engineering, legal/ethics compliance. Good separation of concerns (e.g., separate front-end and back-end testing chapters). Concise titles mostly follow guidelines. Minor issues: some titles slightly verbose (e.g., 'GraphQL & Alternative APIs'), some descriptions could be tighter. Overall exceptional preparation for mastery-level web development.

Very strong curriculum with 82 chapters providing excellent depth across the stack. Notable strengths: strong emphasis on architecture patterns (DDD, microservices), excellent testing coverage, good observability/reliability content, practical topics like payments and content management. Titles are concise. Some descriptions are slightly verbose. Good coverage of emerging tech. Strong career development content. Slight weakness in design/UX coverage compared to top models.

Comprehensive 91-chapter curriculum with excellent breadth. Strong fundamentals coverage and good progression. Notable strengths: ethics chapter, UX principles, offline-first architecture, legacy systems handling. Good career content. Some titles could be more concise (e.g., 'Responsive and Adaptive Design'). Some descriptions are slightly verbose. Good but not exceptional coverage of advanced system design topics compared to higher-ranked models.

Solid 50-chapter curriculum covering core web development comprehensively. Good progression from basics to advanced topics. Includes important modern topics (PWAs, WebAssembly, Web3). Professional practices chapter is valuable. Weaknesses: some titles verbose (e.g., 'Server-Side & Static Site Rendering', 'Relational Databases and SQL' violates guideline). Missing some depth in areas like system design, observability, and advanced architecture patterns. Career chapter is good but brief.

Extensive 116-chapter curriculum with thorough coverage. Strong fundamentals and good separation of CSS topics. Includes practical topics like payment processing, email integration, freelancing. However, granularity is sometimes excessive (e.g., separate chapters for every CSS concept). Some title violations (e.g., 'React Fundamentals', 'Vue.js', 'Angular' use vendor names in titles). Some topics could be consolidated. Good breadth but organization could be improved.

Comprehensive 91-chapter curriculum with solid coverage of web development topics. Good fundamentals and includes emerging tech (Web3, AI integration). Some titles slightly verbose. Missing some advanced architecture depth. Good testing and security coverage. Career chapter present. Weakness: some chapters overlap conceptually, and description quality varies. Framework overview is generic rather than deep.

77 chapters with good overall structure starting from computing foundations. Strong coverage of infrastructure and enterprise topics. Some unique valuable chapters (legacy integration, ethics). However, some titles are too brief/vague (e.g., 'HTML', 'CSS', 'JavaScript' without context). Missing depth in some frontend topics. Some description quality issues. Good but not exceptional career preparation content.

51 chapters providing solid core coverage. Good structure and progression. Strong conceptual focus on framework-agnostic principles. However, lacks depth in many areas critical for top 1% (limited database coverage, minimal microservices depth, weak observability). Some titles verbose (e.g., 'HTML: Structuring the Web'). Missing important practical topics like payments, email, i18n. Insufficient for mastery-level preparation.

59 chapters covering core topics but with notable gaps. Vendor names appear in titles (React, Vue.js, Svelte, Express.js, MongoDB, etc.) violating guidelines. Some chapters too tool-specific rather than conceptual. Missing depth in architecture, observability, and advanced system design. Brief descriptions for some topics. Web3/blockchain included but basic. Career chapter is minimal. Not sufficient for top 1% preparation.

43 chapters - too brief for comprehensive coverage. Missing many essential topics: internationalization, testing depth, advanced architecture patterns, observability beyond basics. No career development content. Descriptions are concise but coverage gaps are significant. Good fundamentals but insufficient for mastery-level preparation. Would not prepare students for advanced roles or complex projects.

Only 32 chapters - severely insufficient scope. Major gaps: no testing chapter, minimal DevOps coverage, no microservices depth, missing i18n, no message queues/event-driven architecture, limited security coverage. Too surface-level for top 1% preparation. Would only cover intermediate-level knowledge at best. Career chapter present but overall curriculum is incomplete.

34 chapters - insufficient depth and breadth. Vendor names in titles (React, Vue.js, Angular, Node.js, MongoDB, etc.) violating guidelines heavily. Missing critical topics: observability, advanced architecture, comprehensive testing, edge computing, WebAssembly depth. Some chapters try to cover too much superficially. Not suitable for preparing top-tier developers. Career chapter is basic.

This model provides the most comprehensive and expert-level curriculum, perfectly aligning with the 'top 1%' goal. It covers advanced and often overlooked topics such as CRDTs, supply chain security, FinOps, GPU/3D on the web, and geospatial features. The content is structured logically from basics to mastery, and titles are concise and fluff-free. It adheres strictly to the constraints, avoiding vendor names in titles (using generic terms like 'Relational databases' instead of 'PostgreSQL') while keeping descriptions technical and precise.

Model J offers an exceptional curriculum with a strong focus on engineering depth (e.g., Data Pipelines, Zero-Downtime Deployments, Edge Auth). It follows the formatting and vendor constraints almost perfectly. It is slightly less granular than Model H but covers the 'Mastery' aspect better than most others by including enterprise architecture and legacy system integration.

This model is very dense and technical, suited for a high-level engineering course. It covers advanced protocols (gRPC), search engines, and compliance well. The descriptions are information-heavy. It loses slightly to H and J due to a specific vendor reference in a description ('Lambda@Edge') which, while relevant, is less generic than the competition.

Model E stands out for its focus on engineering practices like SRE, reliability, and release engineering, which are critical for the top 1%. The titles are concise (lowercase style) and the flow is logical. It is excellent but slightly less comprehensive in breadth compared to the top three.

Model G provides a very balanced curriculum that includes significant coverage of soft skills, ethics, legacy systems, and design collaboration—areas often neglected but vital for leadership roles. The titles are slightly wordier than the models above, but the content quality is high.

Model D offers a solid, standard senior-level curriculum. It covers all the essentials including Docker, Kubernetes, and WebAssembly. It is well-structured and concise but lacks the extreme depth on niche advanced topics found in the top tier models.

Model K provides a good, comprehensive path. It follows the constraints well, though the curriculum feels a bit more standard/generic compared to the expert-level detail of the top models. It uses 'Node.js' in the title, which is acceptable, but overall lacks the 'distinguishing' advanced chapters.

Model A is a decent curriculum but mentions specific tools (npm, yarn, Webpack, Vite) in descriptions more than necessary, and the chapter list is shorter and less detailed regarding advanced architectural patterns compared to higher-ranked models.

Model F follows the formatting rules well but is too brief (42 chapters) to fully satisfy the 'top 1%' and 'mastery' requirement. It covers the basics well but misses deep dives into complex systems and soft skills.

Model L is too shallow for the stated goals, containing only 32 chapters. While the titles are concise and the JSON is valid, it fails to provide the depth required for a PhD-level or mastery-level course.

Model M provides a decent structure but violates the negative constraint regarding vendor names in titles by explicitly listing 'React Fundamentals' and 'Advanced React'. It also has fewer chapters than the top models.

Model C lists multiple specific frameworks (React, Vue, Angular) as separate chapters, which violates the instruction to avoid vendor names in titles. While the list is long, this approach suggests a lack of focus on core concepts over tools.

Model I heavily violates the vendor name constraint, listing specific tools in many titles (React, Vue, Svelte, Next.js, Express.js, PostgreSQL, MongoDB). The descriptions also rely heavily on specific vendors (Vercel, Netlify, AWS Amplify), making the course less timeless and concept-focused.

Most complete and industry-aligned path from fundamentals to advanced practice. Strong coverage of accessibility (including ARIA components and testing), performance (metrics + techniques + profiling), security (OWASP + headers + CORS + identity protocols), backend depth (Node internals, streams/backpressure, data access, query optimization), distributed systems, SRE, supply-chain security, compliance, and modern topics (WebGPU, AI integration, collaboration/sync). Titles are mostly concise and vendor-free. Progression is coherent and prepares for very complex projects and advanced study.

Excellent breadth and sequencing from zero knowledge to senior/lead level: rendering, modern CSS (container queries, cascade layers), front-end architecture, SSR/SSG/hybrid, security, privacy, API paradigms, databases (including SQL mastery), messaging, resiliency, observability, cloud/containers/orchestration/IaC, DDD, release engineering, payments/email/search/analytics. Mostly concise titles and vendor avoidance is good. Slightly less explicit CS/algorithms depth and fewer research-level/advanced distributed-systems specifics than the top entry.

Very strong “top-tier engineer” scope: CS foundations, HTTP/2/3, TypeScript, architecture/system design, caching/search/queues, crypto, SRE/incident response, compliance, experimentation, legacy modernization, and emerging tech. Titles are concise and largely vendor-free. Minor issues: some descriptions are a bit wordy, and it’s less explicitly beginner-friendly in early chapters than others (jumps into CS/complexity quickly).

Comprehensive full-stack-plus curriculum with good progression, strong system design, reliability, security hardening, and leadership/soft skills. Includes advanced patterns (CQRS/event sourcing, incident response, offline-first) and modern web capabilities. Weaknesses: has a duplicate PWA chapter (two separate PWA entries), and overall is somewhat repetitive/long in places; still very good job-readiness and senior-level coverage.

Broad, advanced-leaning roadmap that includes many cross-cutting concerns (observability, performance front/back, edge auth, real-time collaboration, data pipelines, rate limiting, reliability, infra as code). Titles are concise and vendor-free. Gaps: comparatively light on step-by-step front-end specifics (build tooling, browser APIs depth, accessibility testing depth) and on concrete developer workflow basics (CLI, environments).

Solid end-to-end coverage with a reasonable progression and includes leadership and research/trends. However, multiple titles violate the “concise/no fluff” guidance (e.g., “Frontend Frameworks: Core Concepts”, “Responsive Design and Mobile-First Strategy”) and it explicitly mentions package managers (npm/Yarn) in a title/description. Less depth than the best options on observability/SRE, data systems, and modern CSS/modern web capabilities.

Good, structured curriculum from basics through many advanced topics (SSR/SSG, microservices, message queues, IaC, analytics, e-commerce/payments, AI/Web3). Titles mostly concise and vendor-free. Weaknesses: very long list with some redundancy (Design Systems appears twice), and several descriptions drift into “how-to”/exercise-like phrasing; also not as deep on system design/SRE/distributed systems theory as the top outputs.

Decent coverage across front-end/back-end/devops/security with a clear beginner-to-advanced path and mostly concise titles. But it lacks depth needed for leading very complex projects (limited system design/distributed systems, observability, reliability engineering, compliance/privacy, advanced data topics). Also some titles are slightly off-guideline (“CSS Layout Engines”).

Reasonable baseline full-stack outline, but too shallow and compressed for “everything”/top-tier expectations. Missing many advanced areas (observability depth, CI/CD specifics, cloud-native patterns, messaging/eventing, search, privacy/compliance, SRE, leadership). Doesn’t strongly support advanced study preparation beyond a light overview.

Contains many strong topics, but violates constraints and includes vendor/tooling in chapter titles/descriptions (explicit “npm and yarn”, “Webpack and Vite”), which the requirements disallow. Several titles are verbose (“CSS Styling and Layout”, “Server-Side & Static Site Rendering”). Also has some redundancy and uneven depth (e.g., “Server-Side Runtime Environments” is vague) and includes career chapters that add less to technical mastery.

Extremely comprehensive, but heavily violates the “no vendors in titles/descriptions” rule (React, Vue, Angular, Next.js, Redux, Socket.IO, Redis, Memcached, Swagger/OpenAPI, D3.js, GSAP, etc.). Many titles are verbose (“JavaScript Frontend Frameworks Overview”). Despite breadth, the vendor-heavy structure makes it non-compliant with the platform constraints.

Strong modern stack coverage but repeatedly violates the vendor restriction with many explicit vendor/tool names in titles/descriptions (npm/Yarn/pnpm, Vite/Webpack/Rollup, React, Express.js, PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Prisma/TypeORM, GitHub Actions, specific hosting vendors, etc.). Also includes specific UI libraries in a chapter title. Not compliant with the requirements despite decent topical breadth.

High-level and somewhat coherent, but too vendor/framework-centric (React/Next.js, GitHub, Webpack/Vite, AWS/Vercel, Redis, Cypress, Socket.io, React Native) and includes vendors in titles/descriptions. Also lacks depth in many advanced areas (observability, reliability engineering, distributed systems rigor, modern CSS trends, security engineering beyond basics).
